column2: DIVISION B--WEALTH AND RENT
column3: DIVISION B-WEALTH AND RENT

column2: WEALTH AND ITS INDIRECT USES
column3: WEALTH AND ITS INDIRECT USES
one.

column2: If one wishing the hickory-nut hanging above his head must first pick up a stick to throw at it, the nut is removed one step from desire.
column3: If one wishing the hickory nut hanging above his head must first pick up a stick to throw at it, the nut is removed one step from desire.

column2: But even among savages the processes are much more complicated.
column3: But even among savages the processes are much more complicated.

column2: The Indian with a crude knife fashions his bow and arrow, fastens the flint and cord which represent still other processes of industry, and shoots the bird which satisfies his hunger.
column3: The Indian with a crude knife fashions his bow and arrow, fastens the flint and cord which represent still other processes of industry, and shoots the bird which satisfies his hunger.

column2: In modern conditions the relations are vastly more complicated; only at the end of a long series do men arrive at the thing which gratifies their wants.
column3: In modern conditions the relations are vastly more complicated; only at the end of a long series do men arrive at the thing which gratifies their wants.

column2: No agent or influence intervening, a thing may yet be removed a long way from gratification.
column3: No agent or influence intervening, a thing may yet be removed a long way from gratification.

column2: A tree may not be fitted to bear fruit for ten years to come.
column3: A tree may not be fitted to bear fruit for ten years to come.

column2: Meantime, there are many other possible uses for the tree: it may be used for fuel, or to make a canoe with which to catch fish, or to follow some other indirect method of production.
column3: Meantime, there are many other possible uses for the tree: it may be used for fuel, or to make a canoe with which to catch fish, or to follow some other indirect method of production.

column2: The number of steps has no necessary relation to the time.
column3: The number of steps has no necessary relation to the time.

column2: A number of technical steps may be taken in half an hour, or a process of a single technical step may last a year.
column3: A number of technical steps may be taken in half an hour, or a process of a single technical step may last a year.

column2: Many goods of just the same form as the foregoing may not be affording current gratification (except that afforded by thrift and forethought), but are kept because later they will gratify a more intense want or gratify a want better.
column3: Many goods of just the same form as the foregoing may not be affording current gratification (except that afforded by thrift and forethought), but are kept because later they will gratify a more intense want or gratify a want better.

column2: Apples and potatoes are kept in a cellar so that their use is distributed throughout the winter; cider and wine are kept till they get a quality that appeals more to the palate.
column3: Apples and potatoes are kept in a cellar so that their use is distributed throughout the winter; cider and wine are kept till they get a quality that appeals more to the palate.

column2: Coal, wood, and stocks of goods, are thus kept in the form of enjoyable goods, destined to be physically destroyed when at length they yield a gratification. Evidently they must be storing up meantime a certain additional utility, for otherwise there would be no reason why they should be kept for the future.
column3: Coal, wood, and stocks of goods, are thus kept in the form of enjoyable goods, destined to be physically destroyed when at length they yield a gratification. Evidently they must be storing up meantime a certain additional utility, for otherwise there would be no reason why they should be kept for the future.

column2: Such goods as these are sometimes called unripened consumption goods, but until ripened they bear in part the character of durable agents.
column3: Such goods as these are sometimes called unripened consumption goods, but until ripened they bear in part the character of durable agents.

column2: Abiding sources of economic enjoyments are called durable agents.
column3: Abiding sources of economic enjoyments are called durable agents.

column2: The inhabited house is a source of continued gratification in each moment's shelter it affords; but, further, it is the durable source of a series of future uses, as yet unripened.
column3: The inhabited house is a source of continued gratification in each moment's shelter it affords; but, further, it is the durable source of a series of future uses, as yet unripened.

column2: The hammer, the hoe, the tree, the field may all be considered as agents to secure consumption goods.
column3: The hammer, the hoe, the tree, the field may all be considered as agents to secure consumption goods.

column2: Some of these are but one step removed from direct gratification, as the hoe helping the gardener to get food for his own use.
column3: Some of these are but one step removed from direct gratification, as the hoe helping the gardener to get food for his own use.

column2: Yet the classification is practical, corresponding as it does with thoughts which men have in the use of goods.
column3: Yet the classification is practical, corresponding as it does with thoughts which men have in the use of goods.

column2: By repairs and other methods goods become, and are looked upon as, durable sources of a series of uses.
column3: By repairs and other methods goods become, and are looked upon as, durable sources of a series of uses.

column2: It is to be noted further that the enjoyable goods pass over into psychic income, that is, they are the stream of objective utilities that is each moment detaching itself as income from the great mass of wealth. The durable goods are those utilities which for the time remain, not yet ripened or ready to be converted into psychic income.
column3: It is to be noted further that the enjoyable goods pass over into psychic income, that is, they are the stream of objective utilities that is each moment detaching itself as income from the great mass of wealth. The durable goods are those utilities which for the time remain, not yet ripened or ready to be converted into psychic income.

column2: CONDITIONS OF ECONOMIC WEALTH
column3: CONDITIONS OF ECONOMIC WEALTH
one.

column2: Climate is itself a direct source of gratification.
column3: Climate is itself a direct source of gratification.

column2: As temperature must be adjusted to man's need, climate satisfies wants directly.
column3: As temperature must be adjusted to man's need, climate satisfies wants directly.

column2: Health, energy, the beauty of noonday woods and of sunlit clouds are conditioned on the favor of nature.
column3: Health, energy, the beauty of noonday woods and of sunlit clouds are conditioned on the favor of nature.

column2: Climate affects, further, the supply of material economic goods.
column3: Climate affects, further, the supply of material economic goods.

column2: So civilization moved northward from Egypt and India to Greece and Rome, to northern Europe and America.
column3: So civilization moved northward from Egypt and India to Greece and Rome, to northern Europe and America.

column2: Soil conditions for vegetable life determine first the amount and kind of animal life.
column3: Soil conditions for vegetable life determine first the amount and kind of animal life.

column2: Animal life from one point of view is a parasite, living on the vegetable; it is only the vegetable that has power to assimilate most inorganic compounds.
column3: Animal life from one point of view is a parasite, living on the vegetable; it is only the vegetable that has power to assimilate most inorganic compounds.

column2: Man, therefore, depends on the resources of the soil directly or indirectly; a fertile soil furnishes him either directly a supply of vegetable food, or indirectly a supply of animal food.
column3: Man, therefore, depends on the resources of the soil directly or indirectly; a fertile soil furnishes him either directly a supply of vegetable food, or indirectly a supply of animal food.

column2: Natural supplies of metals, of coal, and of timber are important consumption goods, but they are also indirectly the condition for a vast variety of other goods.
column3: Natural supplies of metals, of coal, and of timber are important consumption goods, but they are also indirectly the condition for a vast variety of other goods.

column2: The industry that could exist without iron, copper, and coal would be of a very low grade.
column3: The industry that could exist without iron, copper, and coal would be of a very low grade.

column2: The variety of flora and fauna, and their fitness for man's needs, largely condition the possible production.
column3: The variety of flora and fauna, and their fitness for man's needs, largely condition the possible production.

column2: If, in the course of evolution, it had chanced that wheat and corn, the horse and the cow, had been crowded out in the struggle for existence, we should have had a very different civilization.
column3: If, in the course of evolution, it had chanced that wheat and corn, the horse and the cow, had been crowded out in the struggle for existence, we should have had a very different civilization.

column2: The possibilities of civilization in Peru, and those of all the Indians on the American continent, were limited for lack of domestic animals.
column3: The possibilities of civilization in Peru, and those of all the Indians on the American continent, were limited for lack of domestic animals.

column2: Animals that are fit for domestication are a necessary intermediate agent by aid of which man can appropriate and turn to his use the fertile qualities of the soil.
column3: Animals that are fit for domestication are a necessary intermediate agent by aid of which man can appropriate and turn to his use the fertile qualities of the soil.

column2: Not content with the material world about him, even when it is at its best, man alters it in many ways.
column3: Not content with the material world about him, even when it is at its best, man alters it in many ways.

column2: He enriches the soil, improves the varieties of animals, he even in some slight degree affects the climate, and by the use of a multitude of artificial bits of matter called tools, works profound changes in the world in which he lives.
column3: He enriches the soil, improves the varieties of animals, he even in some slight degree affects the climate, and by the use of a multitude of artificial bits of matter called tools, works profound changes in the world in which he lives.

column2: The outer world is to man the sole source of motive forces.
column3: The outer world is to man the sole source of motive forces.

column2: He can bring things together and they produce the result. Further, it may be said that nearly every kind of utility is conditioned on motion.
column3: He can bring things together and they produce the result. Further, it may be said that nearly every kind of utility is conditioned on motion.

column2: To secure this either he must move to get the goods, or he must cause goods to move toward him.
column3: To secure this either he must move to get the goods, or he must cause goods to move toward him.

column2: The law of "conservation of energy" helps to explain economic action; the supply of energy in the universe cannot be increased or diminished, but may take on new forms.
column3: The law of "conservation of energy" helps to explain economic action; the supply of energy in the universe cannot be increased or diminished, but may take on new forms.

column2: So a limited supply in man's control may take on various forms and so have different effects on gratifications.
column3: So a limited supply in man's control may take on various forms and so have different effects on gratifications.

column2: One and the same source of energy may be converted into the different forms of heat, light, motion, electricity, etc.
column3: One and the same source of energy may be converted into the different forms of heat, light, motion, electricity, etc

column2: But there must be some source. Man's desire is directed to getting force at the right place and in the right degree.
column3: But there must be some source. Man's desire is directed to getting force at the right place and in the right degree.

column2: If light or heat is too intense, it causes pain; the glare of the sun blinds instead of giving keener vision.
column3: If light or heat is too intense, it causes pain; the glare of the sun blinds instead of giving keener vision.

column2: A moderate force applied to any of the senses gives the maximum clearness or pleasure. Man is constantly endeavoring to secure forces from the outer world and to adjust motion so that it will directly or indirectly best serve his purposes.
column3: A moderate force applied to any of the senses gives the maximum clearness or pleasure. Man is constantly endeavoring to secure forces from the outer world and to adjust motion so that it will directly or indirectly best serve his purposes.
three.

column2: There must be a source of energy likewise that mental action may go on, and the power of sunbeams, stored for a time in food, is liberated in the processes of thought.
column3: There must be a source of energy likewise that mental action may go on, and the power of sunbeams, stored for a time in food, is liberated in the processes of thought.

column2: Such a mode is "labor," which becomes at times painful and distasteful.
column3: Such a mode is "labor," which becomes at times painful and distasteful.

column2: In the earliest societies known, some sorts of domestic animals are found supplementing man's efforts and acting upon the material world to alter it for man. The dog joining in the chase guards his master's safety, and helps to bear his burdens.
column3: In the earliest societies known, some sorts of domestic animals are found supplementing man's efforts and acting upon the material world to alter it for man. The dog joining in the chase guards his master's safety, and helps to bear his burdens.

column2: The draft-beast in the field turns the heavy soil, and aids in the final harvest.
column3: The draft beast in the field turns the heavy soil, and aids in the final harvest.

column2: The trained elephant does the work of twenty men piling logs, loading ships, or carrying burdens.
column3: The trained elephant does the work of twenty men piling logs, loading ships, or carrying burdens.

column2: Man further increases his control over the material world by making other men do his bidding.
column3: Man further increases his control over the material world by making other men do his bidding.

column2: Domestic slavery, where wife or child serves the father of the family, or chattel slavery, where the vanquished toils for the victor, are all but universal in early communities.
column3: Domestic slavery, where wife or child serves the father of the family, or chattel slavery, where the vanquished toils for the victor, are all but universal in early communities.

column2: Such a method of increasing one's control over the forces of the world requires only superior strength, no special intelligence in mechanics, and is thus one of the first crude devices in a primitive civilization.
column3: Such a method of increasing one's control over the forces of the world requires only superior strength, no special intelligence in mechanics, and is thus one of the first crude devices in a primitive civilization.

column2: Fuel has been, up to the present time, perhaps the most important source of energy.
column3: Fuel has been, up to the present time, perhaps the most important source of energy.

column2: Fire in the hands of savage man gave him dominion over the forests and over the metals.
column3: Fire in the hands of savage man gave him dominion over the forests and over the metals.

column2: In this age of steam the liberation of the energy of the sun, stored up in coal in ages past, is still the indispensable condition of our developed industry.
column3: In this age of steam the liberation of the energy of the sun, stored up in coal in ages past, is still the indispensable condition of our developed industry.

column2: To make use of the wind for sailing a boat, only the simplest arrangements are needed; a windmill fixed at one place requires more ingenuity and machinery.
column3: To make use of the wind for sailing a boat, only the simplest arrangements are needed; a windmill fixed at one place requires more ingenuity and machinery.

column2: If some means can be found for equalizing the flow and for storing the power of the wind, it may yet become a great agency of industry.
column3: If some means can be found for equalizing the flow and for storing the power of the wind, it may yet become a great agency of industry.

column2: The force of falling water, long used in a petty way by the old water-mills, is just beginning to be employed on a large scale at such points as Niagara.
column3: The force of falling water, long used in a petty way by the old water mills, is just beginning to be employed on a large scale at such points as Niagara.

column2: But the constant motion of the tides offers, at some favored points, a source of power that will remain as long as the earth revolves upon its axis.
column3: But the constant motion of the tides offers, at some favored points, a source of power that will remain as long as the earth revolves upon its axis.
five.

column2: As man grows in power of control over nature, he seeks to apply these forces in forms and at places he has selected.
column3: As man grows in power of control over nature, he seeks to apply these forces in forms and at places he has selected.

column2: He ceases to accept passively its conditions, and to live on its grudging gifts; he becomes its fashioner, in a sense its creator.
column3: He ceases to accept passively its conditions, and to live on its grudging gifts; he becomes its fashioner, in a sense its creator.

column2: His intelligence and his wants are most important factors determining what the form of the physical world about him shall be.
column3: His intelligence and his wants are most important factors determining what the form of the physical world about him shall be.

column2: But all the efforts of men in the most developed economy cannot make to disappear the differences in the quality of goods and agents.
column3: But all the efforts of men in the most developed economy cannot make to disappear the differences in the quality of goods and agents.

column2: Desirable goods to consume are limited in quantity, and they vary in quality; hence they have value and some higher than others.
column3: Desirable goods to consume are limited in quantity, and they vary in quality; hence they have value and some higher than others.

column2: Likewise, durable material agents and sources of power are limited in number and vary in convenience of location and efficiency.
column3: Likewise, durable material agents and sources of power are limited in number and vary in convenience of location and efficiency.

column2: As men seek to gratify their desires, they attach importance to these agents of power.
column3: As men seek to gratify their desires, they attach importance to these agents of power.

column2: Each is valued for its service or its series of services.
column3: Each is valued for its service or its series of services.

column2: When anything is seen to contain a series of uses, it becomes a rent-bearer, and the economic problem of rent arises, one step more complex than the problem of valuing simple consumption goods.
column3: When anything is seen to contain a series of uses, it becomes a rent bearer, and the economic problem of rent arises, one step more complex than the problem of valuing simple consumption goods.
